pageContext.title: How to write a startup value proposition in 5 simple steps
pageContext.content:
Your startup value proposition is what will define your business and distinguish you from your competitors. It is a great way to visualize, design, and test how you can create value for customers and is something that should excite them to do business with you.

If you fail to excite your customers, they won’t buy your product or service.

This article will help you write your own startup value proposition in five simple steps.

The basic principles of a startup value proposition

You need to first understand the basic principles of what a value proposition should consist of. You’ll need to reference back to these points at the end of the five stages to make sure you have a value proposition that excites customers and investors.

A startup value proposition should be:

  • Important to your customer and solve a problem or address a need.
  • Unique and hard to copy.
  • Strong enough to create a buzz and begin word-of-mouth referrals.
  • Short and sweet, so your customer can read and understand it in seconds.

Basically, your value proposition should quickly and clearly outline what your customer will get if they purchase your product or service and why it’s different from your competitors.

A good value proposition

There are many great value proposition examples, but Uber is a company that has nailed it.

In their value proposition, the company discreetly highlights everything that is wrong with traditional taxis, while emphasizing what’s great about its own service at the same time. This image from their website explains the simplicity and convenience of their service:

A screenshot of Uber’s value proposition from their website

Their key features make them stand out because they’re complete contrasts to your traditional taxi experience.

How to write a value proposition in five simple steps

OK, so let’s break things down and start writing your value proposition model.

Step 1: What’s great about you?

A good place to start is to think about what, how, and why:

  1. Write down all the main positives of your product or service and what makes it impressive. This could include the problems it solves, its relative cost, or even its added value.
  2. Next, add the details of how your product or service works. Are there any innovative processes that you follow or do you have a super smart piece of technology making it all happen?
  3. Finally, think about why you do what you do. Ask yourself what your purpose is, how your idea is going to change the world, what it is that gets you out of bed in the morning, and work on your startup idea.

Once you have all these written down, it’s time to move to step two.

Step 2: What do others have to offer?

You now need to look at your competition. Many innovative startups tell us they don’t have any competition. This is almost never the case! Even if your product is the first of its kind, people have tried solving your problem before. That is your competition.

Identify who or what your competition is. Then for each one, write a list of what’s great about the competition (be honest!) and what’s not so great. You might think about features they have that you don’t, their pricing structure compared to yours, or particular problems they may have, such as a negative brand perception.

By the end of this stage, you should have a comprehensive list of the rest of the market in which you are competing.

Step 3: Who do you want to attract and what are they looking for?

You’ll want to identify one core customer profile first. You may end up selling to a number of different sub-segments, but this persona should embody your main customer group. It is possible to do this with a number of different customer profiles, but we find startups get a much better result when they focus on one main audience at the beginning of their journey.

Once you’ve got your persona, think about the pains and gains they have in relation to your product. For pains, think about the problems they are looking to solve, what annoys them, and what risks they fear. For gains, think about what they hope to achieve in their life or career, what would make their life easier, or what they hope others will think of them.

If you’ve got a list of five to 10 pains and gains, it’s time to move onto step four.

Step 4: Why should they choose you?

It’s time to start narrowing down all of this information, so we can start to make sense of it and turn it into a concise value proposition.

First, take a look at the list you created in steps one and two. Now, go through and highlight anything on the list that’s great about you, but different from your competition. These are your unique selling propositions (USPs).

Next, go through the pains and gains for your customer and highlight those that are most important to them. Then, rank these in order of importance. You’ll only want to focus on the top one to three problems to make sure your value proposition is concise.

Step 5: Create your startup value proposition using this template

Use the following value proposition template to create a rough outline for further refinement (if you want a more detailed one, we also created a template you can download here):

For [our customer] who [has this problem], our [product] provides [a summary of the solution]. With [our brand], you [list your main USPs].

For context, here’s Uber’s value proposition:

“For taxi users who are looking for a cheaper, more convenient solution, our ride-sharing app provides fast, reliable rides in minutes. With Uber, you just tap the app and a car comes directly to you without needing to pre-book, and it’s easy to pay with seamless payment through our app.”

***

It may take a few attempts for you to get the language right and select the right combination of problems and solutions. But as long as you follow the steps above, you should be able to nail it pretty quickly. Once you have, you can further expand on each of the USPs listed in your value proposition to form your website and promotional content.

This article was first published on the author’s company blog.
